bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Micajah Perry Senior and Junior, November 8, 1720

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchants Micajah Perry Senior and Junior, November 8, 1720, sending them information about the recent session of the Assembly from which he has just returned, noting that there were disagreements, but "both partys seem to incline to the Govrs. Measures as farr as will be Consistent with the Countrys ability." He turns to Edmund Jenings who has made promises, and Carter states that "If he will not I'll endeavour to make him when I am full Impowerd." He adds that there are rumors that Jenings is to be Secretary [of the colony] but that his commission has not been produced. He comments bitterly "he will be a mighty fortunate man If nobody Else is to come in for a place of Profitt while he lives." In a post script, he requests that the enclosed papers be forwarded to "Col Blackestone."

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Micajah Perry Senior and Junior, November 8, 1720

opener.dateline:
Rappa[hannock, Lancaster County, Virginia]
Novr. 8 1720
Micj. Perry
Senr. & Junr.

div1.p:
I am Just gott home & have ths.
opportunity to send You Copys of the first steps
of our Assembly. The Burgs. are full of quarrels
among themselves both parties seem to incline
to the Govrs. Measures as farr as will
be Consistent with the Countrys ability how their
Jarrs will Issue must be left to time I
hope for the best—

Collo. Jennings promises to be [ . . . ] for
If he will not I'll endeavour to make
him when I am full Impowerd, Im told
he took measures by his Son to pay off his
arrears, of which I shall be glad to hear
Tis said he is appointed Secretary Pro Tempore
his Commission hath not bin produc'd to us
Yett Some Secrett bargains are talked
of that I shall not care to mention till I
know better he will be a mighty fortunate
man If nobody Else is to come in for a place
of Profitt while he lives Yor. acquainted
with his great Merrit as well as any body
but there I leave him at present hoping some
other person may be able to come in for a Share in
the favour of the Crown as well as he, I am
div1.closer:
Gent
Yor. most humb. Servt.
Please to give my
most obedient service
to Col Blackestone to
whom I expect you will
communicate the Enclosed
papers, which I believe
will [ . . . ] arrive to Yor. Shore.

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1720 July-1721 July, BR 227, Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, San Marino, California. Printed: Wright. Letters of Robert Carter. . . . pp. 58-59.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.

[1] Carter had attended meetings of the Council on November 2-5, but apparently had left for home on Saturday, November 6, because he was not present for the meetings the following week. (H. R. McIlwaine. Legislative Journals of the Council of Colonial Virginia. [Richmond: Virginia State Library, 1938-39]. II, 637-640.)
